tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"Next to one of the rivers near Babylon"

tn.ref: we sat ... wept ... we thought ... we hung
tn.text: The writer does not include the readers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Poplar trees do not grow in Israel. "Poplars" may here stand for all the trees in Babylon. AT: "On the trees in Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: our captors required songs from us
tn.text: Here "songs" represents acts of singing. AT: "our captors required us to sing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: one of the songs of Zion
tn.text: This probably refers to songs that the Israelites had used in worship at the temple in Jerusalem.

tn.ref: If I ignore the memory of you, Jerusalem
tn.text: The writer speaks as if Jerusalem is listening to him. AT: "If I act as if I did not remember you, Jerusalem" or "If I try to forget you, Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
the hand most people use most often

tn.ref: Call to mind, Yahweh, what the Edomites did
tn.text: Here remembering what the Edomites did represents punishing them for what they did. AT: "Punish the Edomites, Yahweh, for what they did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Jerusalem being captured by an enemy army is spoken of as if it had fallen. Who captured Jerusalem can be stated clearly. AT: "the day Jerusalem was captured" or "the day the Babylonian army entered Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The psalmist addresses the people of Babylon as if they were there listening to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
This represents the city of Babylon and its people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "may God bless the person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: pays you back for what you have done to us
tn.text: The writer speaks of someone doing to others what they have done as if were payment. AT: "does to you what you did to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: dashes your little ones against a rock
